script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I’m so excited to dive into this week’s study of Moses 1 and Abraham 3. These chapters give us such a profound look at who we are and God’s plan for us. What stands out to you as we start?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, Sarah, there’s so much! I think what hits me right away is the incredible perspective we get on our identity. In Moses 1:4, God tells Moses, 'Behold, thou art my son,' and that just sets the tone for everything. It’s a reminder that our divine identity as children of God is foundational to understanding His plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that. That phrase, 'thou art my son,' feels so personal. It’s like God is making sure Moses—and by extension, all of us—knows exactly who we are before anything else. How do you see that playing out in contrast to what Satan tries to do in the same chapter?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a great connection. In Moses 1:12, Satan comes in and immediately tries to undermine that identity by saying, 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' It’s such a stark contrast—God affirms Moses as His son, while Satan reduces him to just a 'son of man.' It shows how Satan’s tactic is to confuse us about who we really are, to pull us away from our divine potential.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly! It’s almost like Satan offers a counterfeit identity. I’m reminded of President Russell M. Nelson’s teaching in his devotional 'Choices for Eternity,' where he says the first thing the Lord would make sure we understand is our true identity. How do you think knowing we’re children of God helps us resist those counterfeits?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s everything, Sarah. When we internalize that we are children of God, it shapes our decisions and gives us strength to reject Satan’s lies. In Moses 1:13, Moses responds to Satan by saying, 'Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.' That confidence in his identity is what empowers him to stand firm.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s beautiful. I love how Moses doesn’t just defend himself—he points back to his relationship with God. It makes me think about how we can do the same when we’re tempted. What else do you see in Moses’s response that helps him overcome Satan?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Well, one thing that stands out is his persistence in turning to God. In Moses 1:18, after Satan keeps pressing him, Moses says, 'I will not cease to call upon God, I have other things to inquire of him.' He’s not just resisting—he’s actively seeking more light and truth. And by verse 26, we see the Lord’s Spirit sustaining him, which ultimately drives Satan away.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s such a powerful lesson. It’s not enough to just say 'no' to temptation—we need to keep seeking God’s help and guidance. I’m curious, David, how do you see this connecting to what we learn in Abraham 3 about our premortal life?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, there’s a direct tie there. In Abraham 3:22-23, we read about how we existed as spirits 'before the world was,' and God saw our intelligence and chose us for specific purposes. It says, 'These I will make my rulers; for he stood among those that were spirits, and he saw that they were good.' Knowing we were part of God’s plan from the beginning reinforces that identity Moses clings to—it’s eternal!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that connection. It’s like Abraham 3 gives us the backstory to Moses 1. We’re not just children of God now—we were His before we even came to earth. How does that premortal perspective deepen our understanding of God’s purpose for us?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It adds so much depth. In Abraham 3:25, the Lord explains that we’re here to be tested, to see if we 'will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' That purpose ties directly to Moses 1:39, where God declares, 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Our journey, from premortality to now, is all about becoming like Him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so inspiring. God’s entire work and glory is focused on us—on helping us gain eternal life. I’m struck by how personal that feels. What’s the difference, though, between immortality and eternal life in this context?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. Immortality is living forever, which comes through the Resurrection of Jesus Christ for all of us. Eternal life, though, is living with God and becoming like Him, which requires our agency and obedience, as well as Christ’s Atonement. Moses 1:39 shows that God’s ultimate goal isn’t just to save us from death, but to bring us into His presence forever.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That distinction is so important. It’s not just about living forever—it’s about living with purpose and becoming more like our Heavenly Father. Building on that, how do you see Jesus Christ’s role in Abraham 3 fitting into this plan?

script.speaker: David
script.text: He’s central. In Abraham 3:24, we read, 'And there stood one among them that was like unto God, and he said unto those who were with him: We will go down, for there is space there, and we will take of these materials, and we will make an earth whereon these may dwell.' That’s Christ, the Creator under the Father’s direction, and the one who would redeem us. His role was established before the world even began.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s amazing. Christ was there from the very start, chosen to be our Savior. It makes me think about how everything in God’s plan points to Him. How does knowing this about Christ and our premortal life affect the way we live now?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It gives us a sense of purpose and accountability. If we understand that we chose to follow God’s plan in the premortal life, as Abraham 3:26 implies with those who 'kept their first estate,' then our choices here matter deeply. It’s a continuation of that commitment. It also reminds us to rely on Christ, knowing He’s been with us through every step of the plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that idea of continuity. Our life here isn’t random—it’s part of a much bigger story. I think that can help us in tough moments, to remember we’re not just reacting to the present, but fulfilling a divine purpose. What’s a practical way this truth can shape our daily lives?

script.speaker: David
script.text: One way is in how we view challenges. If we see them as part of the test described in Abraham 3:25, we’re more likely to approach them with faith instead of frustration. It also helps us prioritize—knowing our identity as children of God can guide decisions about relationships, time, and even how we treat ourselves. It’s a lens that changes everything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so true. I also think it can impact how we treat others. If I really internalize that everyone around me is a child of God, as Moses 1:4 reminds us, it changes how I interact with them. It fosters more patience and love, don’t you think?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. It’s a reminder that we’re all on this journey together, each with divine worth. That perspective can turn a frustrating moment into an opportunity to lift someone else up, just as Christ does for us. It’s living the plan in real time.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a beautiful way to put it. As we wrap up, David, I’m reflecting on how much these chapters teach us about identity, purpose, and God’s love. What’s one key takeaway you hope listeners hold onto from Moses 1 and Abraham 3?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d say it’s the truth of who we are. We are children of God, with a divine destiny, as Moses 1:6 affirms when God says, 'And I have a work for thee, Moses, my son.' Each of us has a work to do, and God’s glory is in helping us achieve it. That’s a truth worth anchoring to.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I couldn’t agree more. I’d encourage everyone listening to take a moment this week to ponder Moses 1:4 and reflect on what it means to be a child of God. Also, read through Abraham 3:22-28 and list the truths you find about your premortal life. And finally, consider one choice you can make to prioritize your divine identity over any counterfeit labels. David, thanks for such a great discussion!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. I’ve loved exploring these scriptures with you. I hope everyone feels inspired to dive deeper into these chapters and see themselves as God sees them.
